trans-unit.source: Line of business application Phase 3 | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Line of business application Phase 3 | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Create the computers and the SQL Server cluster and enable Availability Groups in Phase 3 of the line of business application in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Create the computers and the SQL Server cluster and enable Availability Groups in Phase 3 of the line of business application in Azure.

trans-unit.source: In this phase of deploying a a high-availability line of business application in Azure infrastructure services, you configure the two computers running SQL Server and the cluster majority node computer, and then combine them into a Windows Server cluster.
trans-unit.target: In this phase of deploying a a high-availability line of business application in Azure infrastructure services, you configure the two computers running SQL Server and the cluster majority node computer, and then combine them into a Windows Server cluster.

trans-unit.source: You must complete this phase before moving on to <linkText>Phase 4</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You must complete this phase before moving on to <linkText>Phase 4</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Deploy a High-Availability Line of Business Application in Azure</linkText><title></title> for all of the phases.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Deploy a High-Availability Line of Business Application in Azure</linkText><title></title> for all of the phases.

trans-unit.source: These instructions use a SQL Server image in the Azure image gallery and are charged ongoing costs for the use of the SQL Server license.
trans-unit.target: These instructions use a SQL Server image in the Azure image gallery and are charged ongoing costs for the use of the SQL Server license.

trans-unit.source: It is also possible to create virtual machines in Azure and install your own SQL Server licenses, but those instructions are not included here.
trans-unit.target: It is also possible to create virtual machines in Azure and install your own SQL Server licenses, but those instructions are not included here.

trans-unit.source: There are two virtual machines running SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: There are two virtual machines running SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: One virtual machine contains the primary database replica of an Availability Group and the second virtual machine contains the secondary (backup) replica.
trans-unit.target: One virtual machine contains the primary database replica of an Availability Group and the second virtual machine contains the secondary (backup) replica.

trans-unit.source: The backup exists to support high-availability.
trans-unit.target: The backup exists to support high-availability.

trans-unit.source: An additional virtual machine is for the cluster majority node.
trans-unit.target: An additional virtual machine is for the cluster majority node.

trans-unit.source: Use the following block of PowerShell commands to create the virtual machines for the three servers. Specify the values for the variables, removing the < and > characters. Note that this PowerShell command set uses values from the following tables:
trans-unit.target: Use the following block of PowerShell commands to create the virtual machines for the three servers. Specify the values for the variables, removing the < and > characters. Note that this PowerShell command set uses values from the following tables:

trans-unit.source: Table M, for your virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Table M, for your virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Table V, for your virtual network settings
trans-unit.target: Table V, for your virtual network settings

trans-unit.source: Table S, for your subnet
trans-unit.target: Table S, for your subnet

trans-unit.source: Table ST, for your storage accounts
trans-unit.target: Table ST, for your storage accounts

trans-unit.source: Table A, for your availability sets
trans-unit.target: Table A, for your availability sets

trans-unit.source: Recall that you defined Table M in <linkText>Phase 2</linkText><title></title> and Tables V, S, ST, and A in <linkText>Phase 1</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Recall that you defined Table M in <linkText>Phase 2</linkText><title></title> and Tables V, S, ST, and A in <linkText>Phase 1</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When you have supplied all the proper values, run the resulting block at the Azure PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: When you have supplied all the proper values, run the resulting block at the Azure PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: For each virtual machine running SQL Server, use the remote desktop client of your choice and create a remote desktop connection to the first domain controller virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: For each virtual machine running SQL Server, use the remote desktop client of your choice and create a remote desktop connection to the first domain controller virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Use its intranet DNS or computer name and the credentials of the local administrator account.
trans-unit.target: Use its intranet DNS or computer name and the credentials of the local administrator account.

trans-unit.source: For each virtual machine running SQL Server, join them to the appropriate AD DS domain with these commands at the Windows PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: For each virtual machine running SQL Server, join them to the appropriate AD DS domain with these commands at the Windows PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: Note that you must supply domain account credentials after entering the Add-Computer command.
trans-unit.target: Note that you must supply domain account credentials after entering the Add-Computer command.

trans-unit.source: After they restart, reconnect to them using an account that has local administrator privileges.
trans-unit.target: After they restart, reconnect to them using an account that has local administrator privileges.

trans-unit.source: Use the following procedure twice, once for each virtual machine running SQL Server, to add the extra data disk and create folders on the new volume.
trans-unit.target: Use the following procedure twice, once for each virtual machine running SQL Server, to add the extra data disk and create folders on the new volume.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane of Server Manager, click File and Storage Services, and then click Disks.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane of Server Manager, click File and Storage Services, and then click Disks.

trans-unit.source: In the contents pane, in the Disks group, click disk 2 (with the Partition set to Unknown).
trans-unit.target: In the contents pane, in the Disks group, click disk 2 (with the Partition set to Unknown).

trans-unit.source: Click Tasks, and then click New Volume.
trans-unit.target: Click Tasks, and then click New Volume.

trans-unit.source: On the Before you begin page of the New Volume Wizard, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Before you begin page of the New Volume Wizard, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select the server and disk page, click Disk 2, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select the server and disk page, click Disk 2, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, click OK.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, click OK.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the size of the volume page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the size of the volume page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Assign to a drive letter or folder page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Assign to a drive letter or folder page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select file system settings page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select file system settings page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Confirm selections page, click Create.
trans-unit.target: On the Confirm selections page, click Create.

trans-unit.source: When complete, click Close.
trans-unit.target: When complete, click Close.

trans-unit.source: Run the following commands from a Windows PowerShell prompt:
trans-unit.target: Run the following commands from a Windows PowerShell prompt:

trans-unit.source: md f:\Data
trans-unit.target: md f:\Data

trans-unit.source: md f:\Log
trans-unit.target: md f:\Log

trans-unit.source: md f:\Backup
trans-unit.target: md f:\Backup

trans-unit.source: Use the following procedure twice, once for each virtual machine running SQL Server, to configure them to use the F: drive for new databases and for accounts and permissions.
trans-unit.target: Use the following procedure twice, once for each virtual machine running SQL Server, to configure them to use the F: drive for new databases and for accounts and permissions.

trans-unit.source: On the Start screen, type SQL Studio, and then click SQL Server 2014 Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: On the Start screen, type SQL Studio, and then click SQL Server 2014 Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: In Connect to Server, click Connect.
trans-unit.target: In Connect to Server, click Connect.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, right-click the top node—the default instance named after the machine—and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, right-click the top node—the default instance named after the machine—and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In Server Properties, click Database Settings.
trans-unit.target: In Server Properties, click Database Settings.

trans-unit.source: In Database default locations, set the following values:
trans-unit.target: In Database default locations, set the following values:

trans-unit.source: For Data, set the path to f:\Data.
trans-unit.target: For Data, set the path to f:\Data.

trans-unit.source: For Log, set the path to f:\Log.
trans-unit.target: For Log, set the path to f:\Log.

trans-unit.source: For Backup, set the path to f:\Backup.
trans-unit.target: For Backup, set the path to f:\Backup.

trans-unit.source: Only new databases use these locations.
trans-unit.target: Only new databases use these locations.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to close the window.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to close the window.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, expand the Security folder.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, expand the Security folder.

trans-unit.source: Right-click Logins, and then click New login.
trans-unit.target: Right-click Logins, and then click New login.

trans-unit.source: In Login name, type domain\sqladmin in (in which domain is the name of the domain in which the sqladmin account was created in Phase 2).
trans-unit.target: In Login name, type domain\sqladmin in (in which domain is the name of the domain in which the sqladmin account was created in Phase 2).

trans-unit.source: Under Select a page, click Server Roles, click sysadmin, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Under Select a page, click Server Roles, click sysadmin, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Close SQL Server 2014 Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: Close SQL Server 2014 Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: Use the following procedure twice, once for each SQL server, to allow remote desktop connections using the sqladmin account.
trans-unit.target: Use the following procedure twice, once for each SQL server, to allow remote desktop connections using the sqladmin account.

trans-unit.source: On the Start screen, right-click This PC, and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: On the Start screen, right-click This PC, and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the System window, click Remote Settings.
trans-unit.target: In the System window, click Remote Settings.

trans-unit.source: In the Remote Desktop section, click Select Users, and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: In the Remote Desktop section, click Select Users, and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: In Enter the object names to select, type [domain]\sqladmin, and then click OK three times.
trans-unit.target: In Enter the object names to select, type [domain]\sqladmin, and then click OK three times.

trans-unit.source: The SQL Server service requires a port that clients use to access the database server.
trans-unit.target: The SQL Server service requires a port that clients use to access the database server.

trans-unit.source: It also needs ports to connect with the SQL Server Management Studio and to manage the high-availability group.
trans-unit.target: It also needs ports to connect with the SQL Server Management Studio and to manage the high-availability group.

trans-unit.source: Next, run the following command at an administrator-level Windows PowerShell prompt twice, once for each SQL Server virtual machine, to add a firewall rule that allows this type of inbound traffic.
trans-unit.target: Next, run the following command at an administrator-level Windows PowerShell prompt twice, once for each SQL Server virtual machine, to add a firewall rule that allows this type of inbound traffic.

trans-unit.source: For each of the SQL Server virtual machines, sign out as the local administrator.
trans-unit.target: For each of the SQL Server virtual machines, sign out as the local administrator.

trans-unit.source: For information about optimizing SQL Server performance in Azure, see <linkText>Performance Best Practices for SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about optimizing SQL Server performance in Azure, see <linkText>Performance Best Practices for SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can also disable Geo Redundant Storage (GRS) for the line of business application storage account and use storage spaces to optimize IOPs.
trans-unit.target: You can also disable Geo Redundant Storage (GRS) for the line of business application storage account and use storage spaces to optimize IOPs.

trans-unit.source: Use the remote desktop client of your choice and create a remote desktop connection to the cluster majority node server virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Use the remote desktop client of your choice and create a remote desktop connection to the cluster majority node server virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Use its intranet DNS or computer name and the credentials of the local administrator account.
trans-unit.target: Use its intranet DNS or computer name and the credentials of the local administrator account.

trans-unit.source: Join the cluster majority node server to the appropriate AD DS domain with these commands at the Windows PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: Join the cluster majority node server to the appropriate AD DS domain with these commands at the Windows PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: Note that you must supply domain account credentials when running the Add-Computer command.
trans-unit.target: Note that you must supply domain account credentials when running the Add-Computer command.

trans-unit.source: After it restarts, reconnect with an account that has local administrator privileges.
trans-unit.target: After it restarts, reconnect with an account that has local administrator privileges.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server AlwaysOn Availability Groups rely on the Windows Server Failover Clustering (WSFC) feature of Windows Server.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server AlwaysOn Availability Groups rely on the Windows Server Failover Clustering (WSFC) feature of Windows Server.

trans-unit.source: The feature allows several machines to participate as a group in a cluster.
trans-unit.target: The feature allows several machines to participate as a group in a cluster.

trans-unit.source: When one machine fails, a second machine is ready to take its place.
trans-unit.target: When one machine fails, a second machine is ready to take its place.

trans-unit.source: Therefore the first task is to enable the Failover Clustering feature on all of the participating machines, which include:
trans-unit.target: Therefore the first task is to enable the Failover Clustering feature on all of the participating machines, which include:

trans-unit.source: The primary virtual machine running SQL Server
trans-unit.target: The primary virtual machine running SQL Server

trans-unit.source: The secondary virtual machine running SQL Server
trans-unit.target: The secondary virtual machine running SQL Server

trans-unit.source: The cluster majority node
trans-unit.target: The cluster majority node

trans-unit.source: The failover cluster requires at least three virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: The failover cluster requires at least three virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Two machines host SQL Server, in which the secondary virtual machine is a synchronous secondary replica, ensuring zero data loss if the primary machine fails.
trans-unit.target: Two machines host SQL Server, in which the secondary virtual machine is a synchronous secondary replica, ensuring zero data loss if the primary machine fails.

trans-unit.source: The third virtual machine does not need to host SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: The third virtual machine does not need to host SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: The cluster majority node functions as a quorum witness in the WSFC.
trans-unit.target: The cluster majority node functions as a quorum witness in the WSFC.

trans-unit.source: Because the WSFC cluster relies on a quorum to monitor health, there must always be a majority to ensure that the WSFC cluster is online.
trans-unit.target: Because the WSFC cluster relies on a quorum to monitor health, there must always be a majority to ensure that the WSFC cluster is online.

trans-unit.source: If only two machines are in a cluster, and one fails, there can be no majority when only one out of two fails.
trans-unit.target: If only two machines are in a cluster, and one fails, there can be no majority when only one out of two fails.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>WSFC Quorum Modes and Voting Configuration (SQL Server)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>WSFC Quorum Modes and Voting Configuration (SQL Server)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For both SQL Server virtual machines and for the cluster majority node, run the following command at an administrator-level Windows PowerShell prompt:
trans-unit.target: For both SQL Server virtual machines and for the cluster majority node, run the following command at an administrator-level Windows PowerShell prompt:

trans-unit.source: Due to current non-RFC-compliant behavior by DHCP in Azure, creation of a Windows Server Failover Cluster (WSFC) cluster can fail.
trans-unit.target: Due to current non-RFC-compliant behavior by DHCP in Azure, creation of a Windows Server Failover Cluster (WSFC) cluster can fail.

trans-unit.source: For details, search for "WSFC cluster behavior in Azure networking" in High Availability and Disaster Recovery for SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: For details, search for "WSFC cluster behavior in Azure networking" in High Availability and Disaster Recovery for SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: However, there is a workaround.
trans-unit.target: However, there is a workaround.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to create the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to create the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Log on to the primary SQL Server virtual machine with the sqladmin account created in <linkText>Phase 2</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the primary SQL Server virtual machine with the sqladmin account created in <linkText>Phase 2</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: From the Start screen, type Failover, and then click Failover Cluster Manager.
trans-unit.target: From the Start screen, type Failover, and then click Failover Cluster Manager.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, right-click Failover Cluster Manager, and then click Create Cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, right-click Failover Cluster Manager, and then click Create Cluster.

trans-unit.source: On the Before You Begin page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Before You Begin page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select Servers page, type the name of the primary SQL Server machine, click Add, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select Servers page, type the name of the primary SQL Server machine, click Add, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Validation Warning page, click **No, I do not require support from Microsoft for this cluster, and therefore do not want to run the validation tests.
trans-unit.target: On the Validation Warning page, click **No, I do not require support from Microsoft for this cluster, and therefore do not want to run the validation tests.

trans-unit.source: When I click Next, continue creating the cluster., and then click **Next.
trans-unit.target: When I click Next, continue creating the cluster., and then click **Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Access Point for Administering the Cluster page, in the Cluster Name text box, type the name for your cluster, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Access Point for Administering the Cluster page, in the Cluster Name text box, type the name for your cluster, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: In the Confirmation page, click Next to begin cluster creation.
trans-unit.target: In the Confirmation page, click Next to begin cluster creation.

trans-unit.source: On the Summary page, click Finish.
trans-unit.target: On the Summary page, click Finish.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, click your new cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, click your new cluster.

trans-unit.source: In the Cluster Core Resources section of the contents pane, open your server cluster name.
trans-unit.target: In the Cluster Core Resources section of the contents pane, open your server cluster name.

trans-unit.source: The IP Address resource appears in the Failed state.
trans-unit.target: The IP Address resource appears in the Failed state.

trans-unit.source: The IP address resource cannot be brought online because the cluster is assigned the same IP address as that of the machine itself.
trans-unit.target: The IP address resource cannot be brought online because the cluster is assigned the same IP address as that of the machine itself.

trans-unit.source: The result is a duplicate address.
trans-unit.target: The result is a duplicate address.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the failed IP Address resource, and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the failed IP Address resource, and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the IP Address Properties dialog box, click Static IP Address.
trans-unit.target: In the IP Address Properties dialog box, click Static IP Address.

trans-unit.source: Type an unused IP in the address range corresponding to the subnet on which the SQL server is located, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Type an unused IP in the address range corresponding to the subnet on which the SQL server is located, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the failed IP Address resource, and then click Bring Online.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the failed IP Address resource, and then click Bring Online.

trans-unit.source: Wait until both resources are online.
trans-unit.target: Wait until both resources are online.

trans-unit.source: When the cluster name resource comes online, it updates the domain controller with a new Active Directory (AD) computer account.
trans-unit.target: When the cluster name resource comes online, it updates the domain controller with a new Active Directory (AD) computer account.

trans-unit.source: This AD account is later used to run the availability group clustered service.
trans-unit.target: This AD account is later used to run the availability group clustered service.

trans-unit.source: Now that the AD account is created, bring the cluster name offline.
trans-unit.target: Now that the AD account is created, bring the cluster name offline.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the cluster name in Cluster Core Resources, and then click Take Offline.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the cluster name in Cluster Core Resources, and then click Take Offline.

trans-unit.source: To remove the cluster IP address, right-click IP Address, click Remove, and then click Yes when prompted.
trans-unit.target: To remove the cluster IP address, right-click IP Address, click Remove, and then click Yes when prompted.

trans-unit.source: The cluster resource can no longer come online because it depends on the IP address resource.
trans-unit.target: The cluster resource can no longer come online because it depends on the IP address resource.

trans-unit.source: However, an availability group does not depend on the cluster name or IP address in order to work properly.
trans-unit.target: However, an availability group does not depend on the cluster name or IP address in order to work properly.

trans-unit.source: So the cluster name can be left offline.
trans-unit.target: So the cluster name can be left offline.

trans-unit.source: To add the remaining nodes to the cluster, right-click your cluster name in the left pane, and then click Add Node.
trans-unit.target: To add the remaining nodes to the cluster, right-click your cluster name in the left pane, and then click Add Node.

trans-unit.source: On the Before You Begin page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Before You Begin page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select Servers page, type the name and then click Add to add both the secondary SQL server and cluster majority node to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: On the Select Servers page, type the name and then click Add to add both the secondary SQL server and cluster majority node to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: After adding the two computers, click Next.
trans-unit.target: After adding the two computers, click Next.

trans-unit.source: If a machine cannot be added, and the error message is "the Remote Registry is not running," do the following.
trans-unit.target: If a machine cannot be added, and the error message is "the Remote Registry is not running," do the following.

trans-unit.source: Log on to the machine, open the Services snap-in (services.msc), and enable the Remote Registry.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the machine, open the Services snap-in (services.msc), and enable the Remote Registry.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Unable to connect to Remote Registry service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Unable to connect to Remote Registry service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: On the Validation Warning page, click **No, I do not require support from Microsoft for this cluster, and therefore do not want to run the validation tests.
trans-unit.target: On the Validation Warning page, click **No, I do not require support from Microsoft for this cluster, and therefore do not want to run the validation tests.

trans-unit.source: When I click Next, continue creating the cluster., and then click **Next.
trans-unit.target: When I click Next, continue creating the cluster., and then click **Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Confirmation page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Confirmation page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Summary page, click Finish.
trans-unit.target: On the Summary page, click Finish.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, click Nodes.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, click Nodes.

trans-unit.source: You should see all three computers listed.
trans-unit.target: You should see all three computers listed.

trans-unit.source: The next step is to enable AlwaysOn Availability Groups using the SQL Server Configuration Manager.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to enable AlwaysOn Availability Groups using the SQL Server Configuration Manager.

trans-unit.source: Note that an availability group in SQL Server differs from an Azure availability set.
trans-unit.target: Note that an availability group in SQL Server differs from an Azure availability set.

trans-unit.source: An availability group contains databases that are highly-available and recoverable.
trans-unit.target: An availability group contains databases that are highly-available and recoverable.

trans-unit.source: An Azure availability set allocates virtual machines to different fault domains.
trans-unit.target: An Azure availability set allocates virtual machines to different fault domains.

trans-unit.source: For more information about fault domains, see <linkText>Manage the Availability of Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about fault domains, see <linkText>Manage the Availability of Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Use these steps to enable AlwaysOn Availability Groups on SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: Use these steps to enable AlwaysOn Availability Groups on SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: Log on to the primary SQL Server virtual machine with the sqladmin account created in <linkText>Phase 2</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the primary SQL Server virtual machine with the sqladmin account created in <linkText>Phase 2</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: On the Start screen, type SQL Server Configuration, and then click SQL Server Configuration Manager.
trans-unit.target: On the Start screen, type SQL Server Configuration, and then click SQL Server Configuration Manager.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, click SQL Server Services.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, click SQL Server Services.

trans-unit.source: In the contents pane, double-click SQL Server (MSSQLSERVER).
trans-unit.target: In the contents pane, double-click SQL Server (MSSQLSERVER).

trans-unit.source: In SQL Server (MSSQLSERVER) Properties, click the AlwaysOn High Availability tab, select Enable AlwaysOn Availability Groups, click Apply, and then click OK when prompted.
trans-unit.target: In SQL Server (MSSQLSERVER) Properties, click the AlwaysOn High Availability tab, select Enable AlwaysOn Availability Groups, click Apply, and then click OK when prompted.

trans-unit.source: Do not close the properties window yet.
trans-unit.target: Do not close the properties window yet.

trans-unit.source: Click the virtual-machines-manage-availability tab, then type [Domain]\sqlservice in Account Name.
trans-unit.target: Click the virtual-machines-manage-availability tab, then type [Domain]\sqlservice in Account Name.

trans-unit.source: Type the sqlservice account password in Password and Confirm password, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Type the sqlservice account password in Password and Confirm password, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: In the message window, click Yes to restart the SQL Server service.
trans-unit.target: In the message window, click Yes to restart the SQL Server service.

trans-unit.source: Log on to the secondary SQL Server virtual machine with the sqladmin account and repeat steps 2 through 7.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the secondary SQL Server virtual machine with the sqladmin account and repeat steps 2 through 7.

trans-unit.source: This diagram shows the configuration resulting from the successful completion of this phase, with placeholder computer names.
trans-unit.target: This diagram shows the configuration resulting from the successful completion of this phase, with placeholder computer names.

trans-unit.source: To continue with the configuration of this workload, go to <linkText>Phase 4: Configure Web Servers</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To continue with the configuration of this workload, go to <linkText>Phase 4: Configure Web Servers</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Deploy a high-availability line of business application in Azure</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Deploy a high-availability line of business application in Azure</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Line of Business Applications architecture blueprint</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Line of Business Applications architecture blueprint</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set up a web-based LOB application in a hybrid cloud for testing</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set up a web-based LOB application in a hybrid cloud for testing</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure infrastructure services implementation guidelines</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure infrastructure services implementation guidelines</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Infrastructure Services Workload: SharePoint Server 2013 farm</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Infrastructure Services Workload: SharePoint Server 2013 farm</linkText><title></title>
